ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
knowledge: what APE is; the various actors, forces, and institutions that play role in it; the many, many venues in which outcomes are determined; where our country has been, is, and goes from here
skills: analyzing arguments in long/complex literature and designing compact responses
insights: american political economy determines everything!!

Knowledge: understanding of the economic and political forces which have shaped America in the last forty or so years, including the role of organized interests, money in politics, spatial inequality, etc

Skills: really honed analytical writing skills, discussion participation skills, reading research papers

Insights: Awareness of the depth of inequality in the US, ways the US diverges from other European nations, and how the strong organization of elites has facilitated a-lot of this inequality, with a strong racial-economic feedback loop
Learned about many different spheres of the American Political Economy.

This course gives students a broad understanding of the burgeoning field of American Political Economy. Lots of very interesting insights into a constantly expanding field of political science research.

I learned a great deal about the American political economy and related topics such as the knowledge economy, race and voting, and resource competition politics. It is a fantastic course that gives students the chance to learn about a new field in political science that brings together a variety of different topics.

During this course, you focus on analyzing the framework of the American political economy across various themes that relate. A heavy emphasis is on the institutions that make up the distinct nature of America, and this course focuses on exploring its uniqueness.

Great introduction to the developing field of the APE. I learned a lot about American institutions and the ways in which they produce distinct outcomes, and developed a nuanced way of thinking about politics and policies in America

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: the most i've ever learned and been pushed intellectually in a course, unreal reading list, assignments allowed individual direction, each class was so well-designed, appropriate length for student presentation
weaknesses: readings were a little long, heavy heavy workload
areas of improvement: some visuals on instructor's end may help

Strengths: the topic is super interesting, Hacker is a great professor, assignments are interesting and keep students engaged
Weaknesses: I think varying up the way students participate may be good, the presentations did this but also perhaps structuring conversations a bit more
Professor Hacker is very knowledgeable and clearly passionate about the material. I personally found the readings to be a bit hit or miss-- some I found super interesting, others not as much.
The class discussions were always great. The readings were interesting and thorough without being prohibitively time consuming. Only weakness is I wish it was in person!

The readings and course format is very well suited to student learning. The discussion papers and student lead conversations made the seminar intriguing and interesting to come to each week. The only weakness is that some of the readings seemed a bit tangential to the topic at hand, but most of them were extremely insightful and beneficial to the course, so no real problem here.

Strengths: The readings which explore various aspects of the course that also allows for each of the students to find a point of interest. Very student led in terms of discussion as well
Weakness: The discussion at times was a bit all over the place and sometimes difficult to find a point of entry

I thought this course was very well structured! I appreciated the four discussion papers and enjoyed weekly presentations. Like all seminars, the quality of discussion depends greatly on the students. There were a few instances where it seemed like a select few people dominated conversations, but aside from that I overall thought it was a well taught class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: all succeeded
The course went pretty smoothly virtually all things considered.

Given that it was a virtual discussion based seminar, it helped a lot to have the Professor call on students who raised their hands, as opposed to in person seminars where people just tend to jump in.
The Covid accommodations were as successful as possible!
The student led discussions component of the course allowed for more interesting discussions and made seminar fun to attend and participate in.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 110% - once-in-a-lifetime experience to learn from a world-class expert about supremely important material

Yes! It is definitely a challenging course and you must be prepared to engage with tough content and work hard on essays but the topic is so so interesting and Jacob Hacker is an expert in the nascent field, so it's super interesting to learn from him and the other students who are also very knowledgeable.
Absolutely. Any student interested in public policy and economic issues should take the course.

Yes, absolutely. I believe that anyone involved in or interested in American politics should familiarize themselves with the most pertinent topics of the nation's political economy and that's exactly what this course does.

I would highly recommend this course. Professor Hacker is a wonderfully engaging instructor who has deep knowledge on the topic area and works to ensure students are finding interesting niches of the course to explore and excel in. This course is great in garnering a deeper understanding of the American political economy and many facets of American politics.

I would recommend this to anyone who has an interest in American politics and its institutional makeup. This however is a course geared towards those that have completed a few courses in the Poli-Sci major already

I would recommend this course if you have a strong background in economics and American political science. The first few weeks were a little dense in terms of the economic theories, but I genuinely enjoyed the latter part of the course once we got more into the sociological work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
N/A
Weekly readings, discussion papers, and a final paper
